thread.title: Argonauts' Van Roten a versatile weapon
thread.title_full: Argonauts' Van Roten a versatile weapon

title: Argonauts' Van Roten a versatile weapon
text:
BMO Field to host 2016 Grey Cup: Source 
What a whirlwind it has been for Greg Van Roten, moving here and there and everywhere along the line of scrimmage, forced to play home games in northern Alberta, the nation’s capital and now in the home stadium of the Argos’ most heated rival. 
As a first-year player, Van Roten doesn’t know any better, no reference point to compare and contrast the plight of the Argos this season, which remains at the mercy of baseball, at least from a stadium perspective. 
As a highly accomplished lineman, Van Roten has such a high football IQ, not to mention scholastic prowess having attended an Ivy League school in Penn, he can do just about anything, no matter where he’s asked to line up. 
Judging line play requires a keen eye from the most astute of football people or the benefit of watching a game film. 
From afar, Van Roten is having a spectacular season, his stock increasing each time he starts at a new position. 
Van Roten and Tyler Holmes are the only offensive linemen to start for the Argos this season. 
Holmes has been ensconced at left guard, while Van Roten has rotated from centre, guard and tackle. 
In camp, he lined up at guard. 
When veteran Jeff Keeping was injured, Van Roten began the season as Toronto’s starting centre. 
When Keeping returned, Van Roten returned to guard. 
Chris Van Zeyl injured his calf in Ottawa, forcing the Argos to look at their best option for the team’s trip to Montreal on Thanksgiving Monday. 
Enter Van Roten. 
Van Roten was asked to explain the challenges a player faces when he’s asked to line up in different position. 
“The timing of the players you’re going up against,’’ he said. “When you’re a guard you know there still a yard off, but they are on your shoulders, inside you, so you can time it up. 
“At tackle, guys can be four yards outside you and you have to really learn to not overset them and that’s what I’m trying to work on. And the other side to that is if you’re too slow in your set then they’ll just beat you upfield. You have to find a happy medium with your sets. The timing is the biggest thing and then the body type of the guy you’re playing against. 
“Inside guys are typically bigger, outside guys are typically more athletic, leaner and they just present different issues.” 
Van Roten has played each position along the line during his career, but he’s quick to point out one difference he’s experienced as an Argo. 
“Never in one season,’’ he quipped. “It’s definitely a challenge to switch from position to position. It’s been an experience, but I’m trying to do my best.” 
Whether Van Roten is the best, only coaches and opponents truly know. 
What’s known is that Van Roten has emerged as a very nice piece for the Argos, versatile and intelligent to attack whatever is thrown his way, whether it’s on the fly in game or having the benefit of practice time. 
In Week 3 when the Argos played in Calgary, Van Roten started at centre. 
This Saturday, he’ll line up at right tackle. 
“Schematically, they’re all over the place,’’ Van Roten said of the Stamps defence, which is led by co-ordinator Rich Stubler. “Some weeks they’re vanilla, some weeks they’re coming from everywhere. We got to be prepared for everything. 
“It’s the CFL and every week it’s a different animal.” 
ELLIOTT NOT AVAILABLE 
If anything, the Argos have shown that no obstacle is big enough to overcome, no amount of adversity onerous to tackle. 
Anyone who has remotely followed the Argos this season is well aware of the schedule and the unavailability of Rogers Centre with post-season baseball back in town. 
The Argos will have a home game in Hamilton this Saturday and likely add next Friday’s visit by Montreal to the growing list. 
It’s not an ideal way of doing business in the cut-throat business of football, but when a starter becomes unavailable, the next-man-up philosophy gets embraced. 
Kevin Elliott, one of the many new faces who have made an impact this season, wasn’t at practice Thursday and he won’t be playing against the Stamps for personal reasons. 
Only once this season has Elliott missed a game, but when the Argos visited Winnipeg in August the receiver didn’t make the trip after he suffered a rib injury. 
Elliott has eight receiving touchdowns, one of the primary go-to targets for Trevor Harris in the red zone. 
Tori Gurley, another of Toronto’s new faces, leads the team with nine receiving majors. 
KICKING AROUND OPTIONS 
Given the game of musical chairs the Argos have played this season with their punting game, nothing should ever be considered as a done deal. 
Just when the Argos thought they had signed Billy Pavlopoulos, the Canadian failed to pass his physical. 
Enter Brett Lauther, who was at practice yesterday, the same day injured punter/kicker Swayze Waters ran on the adjoining track for the second day in a row. 
Waters is getting closer and when healthy he gives the Argos their best option, an all-star who can handle all three kicking facets. 
Unless something crazy happens between now and Saturday afternoon’s 4 p.m. kickoff against Calgary as the Argos play a home game in Hamilton, it appears Justin Palardy will serve on all the team’s kicking duties. 
Palardy had a rough game Thanksgiving Monday, missing two field goals, but he was perfect as Toronto won both of its games in Ottawa, the first visit featuring American Michael Palardy along with the Canadian Palardy. 
The Argos can always bring in an American, but Waters is close and it makes no sense if it means adjusting the ratio. 
frank.zicarelli@sunmedia.ca
